Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The early evolution and adaptive radiation of saurian reptiles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Reptiles form a critical component of the modern ecosystem, with over 20,000 known species. Fossil and molecular evidence shows that all of these living species belong to a single group, Sauria, which originated over 260 million years ago, during the Permian Period. Although saurians are rare in the Permian fossil record, they become common and diverse following a massive extinction event at the end of the Permian, 252 million years ago. This end-Permian extinction occurred at the same time as massive volcanic eruptions and acidification in oceans, wiping out an estimated 95% of species living at the time. The saurians that appear after the extinction very quickly evolve an incredible diversity of body sizes, body shapes, and diets, suggesting that they took advantage of the many gaps in the ecosystem caused by the extinction. However, the family tree of the oldest Sauria is poorly understood, and critical questions about the ancestors of all modern reptiles remain unanswered: How does the diversity of Sauria change over the period of environmental change at the end of the Permian? How rapidly did the early saurian groups change anatomically? What did the ancestor of all living reptiles look like, and how have the lineages we see today changed from that ancestor? Answering these questions will allow scientists to understand the impact that similar environmental changes occurring today, could have on living animal species. It will also provide a baseline for the changes we might expect following more serious environmental crises.

Fossils from the Permian and Triassic periods are far too ancient to preserve DNA, and reconstructing their evolutionary history must rely on detailed anatomical study. Unfortunately, the anatomy of most early saurians have not been well described. This dissertation project has required restudy of dozens of museum collections worldwide, funded largely by grants from private foundations. These allowed development of the largest anatomical dataset analyzing this critical problemThese museums preserve fossils from the Karoo Formation of South Africa, a critical region that preserves a huge diversity of early diapsids from both the latest Permian and earliest Triassic,, providing an unprecedented opportunity to sample fossils at this critical moment. The dataset constructed and the photo records developed for this project will be made available to the public via NSF-funded databases (e.g., Morphobank).

POR.DRECONTENT:
I received this research award to study the first stage of evolution for one of the most important groups of backboned animals alive today: the reptiles. Representing nearly 20,000 living species when you include the birds (descendants of dinosaurs), the emergence of reptiles was one of the most successful events in the history of evolution. This initial evolution also occurred around the time of the 250 million-year-old Permo-Triassic Extinction (PTE for short), the largest-known mass extinction in Earth’s history. The PTE saw the extinction of ~90% of known fossil species during a period of massive volcanic eruptions and desertification. However, the fossil record of the earliest reptiles is very poorly understood, leaving major questions open for scientific scrutiny:

1)    When did the first reptile groups diverge from one another?

2)    When did the first reptile groups begin changing anatomically?

3)    How rapidly did these events occur?

The phases of this research involved 1) the description of new, small reptile species from the Triassic Period (~212 my ago) with implications for early reptile evolution, 2) the study of relevant fossil reptile species from around the world, and 3) the development of a computer dataset to reconstruct the phylogeny (effectively, the “family tree”) of early reptiles. The NSF funds from this grant allowed me to travel to museums in South Africa and the United Kingdom that contain fossils from the earliest stage of reptile evolution (~250 my old). For most of these fossils, there are no published images or three-dimensional models; traveling to the museums is still the best way to understand their anatomy. Fortunately, I took several thousands photographs of the fossils which will be incorporated into publications. Amazingly, some of the fossils I studied have been in collections for nearly two centuries, and yet I STILL found anatomical features that had never been reported before.

            Following my research trips, I have the following answers to the questions for this research project:

1)    The first reptile groups diverged from one another before the Permo-Triassic Extinction. Indeed, my research suggests that more groups survived the PTE than any prior study of early reptiles. This owes largely to a complete, three-dimensional skull of a bird-like reptile from the Triassic Period of New Mexico that preserves many incredibly primitive anaotmical features. I would not have been able to analyze this skull with studying fossils of close relatives from the time of the PTE in South African museums.

2)    The results of my study are preliminary, but my “family tree” strongly suggests that the anatomy of the earliest reptiles was quite diverse and varied both before and after the PTE. It is not yet clear how severely reptiles were impacted by the environmental problems around the PTE. However, the analyses from my dissertation research and its resulting papers strongly support the hypothesis that many individual families of Permian reptiles survived the PTE and went on to thrive in the subsequent Triassic Period. When those groups first appear in the Triassic fossil record, they are already very different from one another anatomically. This pattern of survival, in which a large number of groups survive and appear to become anatomically diverse VERY quickly in the fossil record is widely understood; the ancestors of both modern birds and placental mammals follow a very similar pattern during the time of the end-Cretaceous mass extinction that wiped out the dinosaurs. It now appears that the ancestors of modern reptiles followed a very similar pattern almost 200 million years prior.

3)    My studies suggest a very rapid evolution of both families and anatomies during the time surrounding the PTE. However, the speed of evolution is very difficult to understand in times when the fossil record is quite poor. My analyses suggest that the Late Permian and Early Traissic periods—some of the most environmentally unstable times in Earth’s history—were the times when the diversity of reptiles “took off.” Fragmentary fossils from this time period that I did study suggest that there are many, many undiscovered groups of reptiles from the post-extinction time that have yet to be fully understood.

I have published initial results of my dissertation research and analyses of small-bodied Triassic reptiles in Current Biology, PLoS One, and the Journal of Vertebrtae Paleontology. I presented several public talks about my work and the science of extinction at Yale University, the American Museum of Natural History, and PaleoFest 2015. I also produced a natural history podcast about some of my dissertation work available at http://pasttime.org/. I am continuing to develop the analyses from my dissertation for future projects involving more reptilian diversity from the dawn of the Mesozoic Era.
